channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Let’s do an experiment! Perl role in Canberra, Australia
item.description: Attention, Perl programmers. We’re looking for those among you who loved their childhood chemistry sets and could spend hours studying their ant farms. Science buffs and genetics junkies, our client wants to hear from you. You’ll be familiar with modern tooling and might have experience with Ansible, AWS, and Linux containers. MySQL, Postgres, and Solr are all nice-to-haves.

item.title: Pop Quiz and Your New Perl Role! 100% Remote within UK
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: What would your computer say about you? Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: Our client is the worldwide leader in machine intelligence for matching people with jobs, which is to say that when it comes to hiring, they know what they’re doing. Applicants, bring your “A” game: they’re looking for a Natural Language Processing (NLP) Engineer who is passionate about Machine Intelligence and can evaluate NLP systems.

item.title: Perl Superheroes Wanted! Remote Perl within US time zone
item.description: As the leading provider of award-winning intelligent SaaS solutions for clients that include first responders, engineers, manufacturers, and educators, this organization’s comprehensive offerings include training management, continuing education, compliance training, safety management, and workforce scheduling. They’re looking for a Perl developer with Catalyst and DBlx::Class.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Crystal course starting today
item.description: Join Gabor at his Programming Crystal course?

item.title: Weekly Challenge 120
item.description: I am impressed with regex solution for the task #1, very compact as always. Keep up the great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 120: Swap Clock
item.description: Roger came up with one-liner using bitwise operator that makes it look really cool. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 120
item.description: For me the highlight was the one-liner Perl solution to the Clock Angle task. Cool solution.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 120: quick and dirt
item.description: Luca solution to the Clock Angle task is unbelievably simple. Simply genious. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 120: Swap Odd/Even Bits and Clock Angle
item.description: Laurent never miss the opportunity to show off his Raku knowledge. I have learnt a lot from him. Keep sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #120
item.description: James always comes up with compact solution. This week also he came up with clinical approach with bit operation. Well done.

item.title: TWC 120: Task #1, Swap Odd/Even bits & Task #2, Clock Angle
item.description: I liked the story telling format. It tells the story behind each action.

item.title: PWC120 - Clock Angle
item.description: The highlight of Flavio is not limited to Perl but also Raku. You will find lots of magics from both world.

item.title: PWC120 - Swap Odd/Even bits
item.description: Flavio explained the bit operation so brilliantly that any layman can understand. Thank you for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Getting Oddly Even in a Clean Sweep
item.description: You simple don't want to miss the narrative behind each task. Keep up the great work.

item.title: CY's Take on The Weekly Challenge #120 ‐ Histories, Experiences, Reflections
item.description: Cheok-Yin blog is always fun to read. I am pleasantly surprised to see Team PWC share information and help each other.

item.title: https://raku-musings.com/even-clock.html
item.description: Arne has been brilliant with his blog title. You simply can't beat him. Also the pictorial description of the solution is incredibly useful. Keep up the great work.

item.title: Swapping Bits / Time Angle
item.description: I noticed something new in the both solutions, use of MAIN: {}. Never seen this before, something to explore later, thanks for sharing knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 120: Clock Angle
item.description: A very different approach to the clock angle task. There is plenty to learn from his work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 120: Swap Odd/Even bits
item.description: Abigail once again showing his class with one-liner. Don't miss out the fun. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 120
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Swap Odd/Even bits" and "Clock Angle" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 121
item.description: Welcome a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Invert Bit" and "The Travelling Salesman". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: App::Easer
item.description: App::Easer finally uploaded to CPAN.

item.title: How I Uploaded a CPAN Module
item.description: Cheok-Yin first hand experience on how to upload to CPAN module.

item.title: Release notes for Rex 1.13.4
item.description: This patch release of the friendly automation framework contains documentation updates, and fixes inconsistent behavior between the `content` and `source` options of the file command.

item.title: Perl Language Server (PLS) - Visual Studio Marketplace
item.description: If you are Visual Studio Code user then this annoucement is for you.

item.title: #520 - CPAN Bus Factor
item.description:
Hi there

If you are fan of MetaCPAN, like me, then you must have noticed the latest changes to MetaCPAN site. It is the introduction of new metric, "CPAN Bus Factor". Don't know what I am talking about? Well then you should read the blog, which is the collaborative work by Neil Bowers and Olaf Alders.

It reminds me an incident from the past when I received an email from Neil Bowers about one of my CPAN distribution, IP::Info as he was reviewing CPAN modules for locating an IP address. Later he published his report on 8th Aug 2012. You can take a look collection of CPAN module reviews by him. If my memory serves better, Neil also ran CPAN Weekly, for some times. I did join the mailing list and received CPAN Weekly newsletter talking about a CPAN module and it's usage every week. Unfortunately it is no longer active.

Long time ago, I used to be an active CPAN contributor. Unfortunately because of time constraint, I no longer remain as active as I used to be. I even wrote 2-parts blog on the subject "How to become a CPAN contributor?" for perl.com in 2018. You can checkout the blogs, Part 1 and Part 2, if you are interested.

Why am I talking about CPAN contribution?

A friend of mine and fellow contributor to The Weekly Challenge, Cheok-Yin Fung, wrote a blog about her experience on uploading her first distribution on CPAN. It reminds me of my early days of struggle with CPAN. These days there are so many help available on various public platforms. I wish her all the best and welcome to the club of CPAN contributors.

I came across a very interesting blog by JJ Merelo talking about Pull Request do's and don'ts. A very helpful advice for anyone looking to contribute to opensource projects in general.

Enjoy the rest of the newsletter.
